After I found three Black women named "Singh" in the 1940 Census, I looked them up using #genealogy sites like Ancestry:

(1) The first was Ellie Singh, aged 58, was born in Alabama, designated "Negro," and listed as a homemaker.

She lived in Chicago with husband Juar Singh, age 52, born in India, working as a herb doctor.

They lived with their 18 year old son Lester, marked Negro like his mother, and currently attending high school.

What do you with a history dataset?

I started by exploring the data with #Tableau.

Here's what I discovered about the Singhs in the 1940 US Census:

• most were in California

• immigrant men had an average age 51 (so old!) — maybe due to 1920s immigration restrictions?

• the majority of non-Indian wives were from former/current Mexico

• Singh men could be designated "Hindoo" or "White"

I wrote this blog post that explains why:

https://secretdesihistory.com/the-1940-singh-census-and-the-attack-on-indian-immigrants-7fcd8e16c5e

3/n

The first significant wave of South Asians on the West Coast of the US were Punjabi men, primarily Sikh (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Punjabi_Americans)

Some of those histories are well recorded: Stockton Gurdwara, railroads, Punjabi-Mexican marriages, Bellingham Riot: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Punjabi_Americans

I wanted to do some #DigitalHumanities analysis, so I created a cleaned-up list of every person with the last name "Singh" in the 1940 US Census.

I made the dataset public:

https://github.com/anirvan/1940-singh-census/
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Singh

title: Man beats machine at Go in human victory over AI

last_post.content:
I think this will be harder to fix than most people expect. AlphaGo and similar techniques work by using deep learning to guide the game tree search, focusing it on moves used by experts. This result says you can't do that, that you need to consider more possible moves. The human won by doing moves the AI didn't expect, then exploiting the result. Solving that means considering more moves by the opponent, which explodes the game tree search. It's going to be hard to fix.
https://arstechnica.com/information-technology/2023/02/man-beats-machine-at-go-in-human-victory-over-ai/

title: Lila, violett och gredelin – därför byter vi ord för färger - forskning.se

last_post.content:
Partner noted something I had not though of: in Swedish all blue-red colors, even dark ones, are called ”lila” (lilac) instead of ”violett” (violet). Turns out the Swedish word for the color is unstable and has been changing since the 19th C. There is a doctoral thesis about it. In the Middle Ages, these colors were called browns! #color #language

https://www.forskning.se/2017/03/08/lila-violett-och-zombieordet-gredelin/#

title: Explainable Data-Driven Optimization: From Context to Decision and Back Again

last_post.content:
Decision-support systems need user confidence to go into production. This is especially critical for hybrid #MachineLearning + #ORMS pipelines. So, how to explain data-driven decisions based on contextual information? We introduce new methodologies: https://arxiv.org/abs/2301.10074

We provide counterfactual explanations highlighting why a solution is better than another (or any other) due to context, e.g., in which context should we use the green path instead of the blue path (or any other path) today?

Why are so many people seeing more engagement on Mastodon than Twitter?

To me, the answer is pretty simple: Twitter tries to aggregate as much attention as possible around stuff that goes mega-viral.

There are only so many minutes in the day. So for stuff to "blow up big" necessitates that most of the rest of the posts from people we might actually want to hear from must go unseen.

title: Thank This World War II-Era Film Star for Your Wi-Fi

last_post.content:
Born in 1914, Hedy Lamarr was a famous American actress who pioneered the technology that would lead to WiFi, GPS, cell phones & Bluetooth communication.

Lamarr was brilliant. Among many fascinating inventions, she developed a new communication system with composer George Antheil that used “frequency hopping” among radio waves.

Once called the “most beautiful woman in the world," Lamarr is now remembered as "the mother of Wi-Fi."
